citeinfo.title: CHGIS Version 4 : GNS China 1990 Placenames in Shaanxi Province

descript.abstract:
point features showing populated places and natural features in Shaanxi Province, China (circa 1990)
1990 GNS Placenames
New for Version 4 are more than 140,000 U.S. GeoNames Database features, enhanced with parent jurisdiction information. All of the China placename features (including towns, administrative units, and natural features) have been stamped with their parent county names, prefecture names, and national standard code numbers (GuoBiao Codes) for those parent jurisdictions. The resulting files have been split into thirty separate layers, one for each Chinese Province (circa 1990).
Chinese Characters are included for County level units only (GBK encoding).
This data is derived from public domain GNS data, published by the U.S. Board on Geographic Names (please consult GNS_COPYRIGHT statement, included with each layer). -- text from CHGIS v4 CD-ROM.
descript.purpose:
Extracted from the Geographic Names Database, U.S. Board on Geographic Names. See: http://earth-info.nga.mil/gns/html/
The China Historical Geographic Information System (CHGIS) project is designed to provide a GIS platform for scholarly and scientific research. Considerable flexibility has been designed into the GIS, allowing for alternate versions and variations of feature attributes, spatial data, and competing political entities. The CHGIS aims to build a reliable database of administrative units and settlements, but does not wish to impose a closed interpretation on the relationships among those units. The advantage of creating the CHGIS, rather than printing paper maps, is that the relationships between the units can be modified and improved whenever new information becomes available and the new "edition" needs only to be posted on the Internet for users to download. The CHGIS editors have set high editorial standards for the inclusion of material in the CHGIS time series data and regulate the release of the official versions from designated CHGIS participating organizations. Users may search the database for administrative units and capitals for any given time in Chinese history, can create customized digital maps for particular times and places, or can join their own datasets for spatial analysis, thematic mapping, or other specialized statistical modeling according to their own interests.
descript.supplinf: Projected for use with CHGIS Version 4 [Gauss Kruger Xian 1980 Zone 19]

timeperd.current: sources from various dates up to 1990

idinfo.accconst: See README_GNS_COPYRIGHT enclosed with this dataset: http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~chgis/data/chgis/downloads/v4/datasets/README_GNS_COPYRIGHT.txt
idinfo.useconst: Academic use of CHGIS data is allowed, and encouraged, provided that any derived data or digital images of maps give proper citation to CHGIS as stated above. The CHGIS datasets are distributed for non-commercial academic research purposes only. Any organization or individual that makes commercial or revenue generating use of the CHGIS Datasets must first obtain a licensing agreement from CHGIS Management Committee. Use of the datasets distributed on CD-ROM or downloaded from CHGIS websites implies acceptance of all the terms stated in the End User's License Agreement (http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~chgis/data/chgis/downloads/v4/EULA.txt), and acknowledges understanding of any liabilities stated therein by the end-user.
idinfo.datacred: "GNS Country Files, China." Geographic Names Database U.S. Board on Geographic Names, 2000.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.0.1324

citeinfo.title: GNS China 1990 Placenames in Shaanxi Province

procstep.procdesc: ArcMap was used to edit the source shape files and delete the values in any columns containing Chinese characters, then the ArcGIS 9.2 Feature Class to Feature Class tool was used to move the geographic shapes into SDE. Microsoft Access was used to import the CHGIS-provided text file containing the properly encoded attribute values. A new text file containing just attributes with Chinese characters was created with the proper encoding, either GBK or UTF-8 depending on the source. This text file was imported to a new table in Oracle using SQLLoader with the NLS_CHARACTERSET property set to either UTF8 or ZHS16GBK. The attributes were then joined back to the shapes using Windows SQLPlus with the NLS_LANGUAGE property set to Traditional Chinese. This process ensured that the encoding was properly interpreted during the import.

attr.attrdef: County name (Chinese)
Feature Designation Code. A two to five-character code used to identify the type of Geoname feature a name is applied to.

First-order administrative division code. A two alpha-numeric code from the FIPS 10-4 Standard describing a primary administrative division of a geopolitical entity, such as a state in the United States.

A form of the full name that allows for alphabetical sorting of the file into gazetteer sequence. All character/diacritic combinations and special characters are substituted with QWERTY (visible U.S. English keyboard) characters, all characters are upper-cased, numerals are converted to lower-case characters (0-9 = a-j), spaces are stripped out, and commas replaced with space. The substitution is done according to a character mapping table that is Region Font Code specific (see Character Set Conversion Table: http://earth-info.nga.mil/gns/html/Char_sets_20060703.pdf) This field is included for the benefit of the end user of the data to aid in the sorting of names if required.
Feature geometry.
Unique Feature Identifier. A number which uniquely identifies a Geoname feature.

Region Font Code. A code that determines the character mapping used in the SHORT_FORM, Generic, and Full_Name fields (see Character Set Conversion Table http://earth-info.nga.mil/gns/html/Char_sets_20060703.pdf)
Latitude of the Geoname feature in +/- degrees, minutes, and seconds; DMS; (+/-ddmmss): no sign (+) = North; negative sign (-) = South.
Longitude of the Geoname feature in +/- degrees, minutes, and seconds; DMS; (+/- dddmmss) : no sign (+) = East; negative sign (-) = West.
Military Grid Reference System
Unique Name Identifier. A number which uniquely identifies a name.

Universal Transverse Mercator coordinate grid reference. (This character field is derived from the system generated and stored Military Grid Reference System (MGRS) coordinates when this file is generated.)
Joint Operations Graphic reference.
Latitude of the Geoname feature in +/- decimal degrees; DD; (+/- dd.dd...): no sign (+) = North; negative sign (-) = South.
Feature Classification: Nine (9) major Geoname feature categories into which similar feature designations are grouped.

edom.edomvd: Streets, highways, roads, or railroad type feature

attr.attrdef: Populated Place Classification. A graduated numerical scale denoting the relative importance of a populated place. The scale ranges from 1, relatively high, to 5, relatively low. The scale could also include NULL (no value) as a value for populated places with unknown or undetermined classification.
Primary Country Code. A two alphabetic character code uniquely identifying a geopolitical entity (countries, dependencies, and areas of special sovereignty).
Second-order administrative division. The name of a subdivision of a first-order administrative division, such as a county in the United States.
Name Type

edom.edomvd: BGN Standard name in non-Roman script
Not verified name in non-Roman script

attr.attrdef: Longitude of the feature in +/- decimal degrees; DD; (+/- dd.dd...): no sign (+) = East; negative sign (-) = West.
A part of the full name that could substitute for the full name.
The descriptive part of the full name such as Mount, River, or Sea (generally does not apply to populated place names).

The full name is a complete name which identifies the named feature. It is comprised of the specific name, generic name, and any articles or prepositions. The query returns the specific part of the name first followed by a comma and then the generic part and any article or prepositions. Names that are enclosed in double parenthesis (( Name )) are features that are believed to no longer exist. User should click on the returned name to receive any additional names for the feature.
Name (ASCII)
Province name
Prefectural level unit code.
Prefecture name (Pinyin)
County name (Pinyin)
County level unit code
Internal feature number.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Feature geometry.
